comments.commentBody: And I would add that politicians who fail to raise the debt ceiling are like deadbeat dads who don't pay child support.  The debt ceiling is related to expenditures already incurred,  not future spending.

The first order of business, however, is to make sure the vast majority of the public even knows what the debt ceiling is and does. Just today, Republican members of Congress were on the TeeVee accusing our president of spending and then using the debt ceiling to spend some more... Most people have no idea and are quite content to believe the Very Serious members of Congress.

Americans need to revisit and in most cases re-learn the Constitution.  The 14th Amendment, Section 4 states ‘The validity of the public debt of the United States … shall not be questioned.’ Congress, having already spent the money have incurred the debt. The way it works is that Congress goes to the Treasury and says "We appropriated so many dollars to pay for running the govenment of the US and now we need you to release the funds so that we act as required by the Constitution."  In other words, the Constitution took the debt ceiling off the political table as the 14th amendment intended.  What is going on with these Republicans who wish to make the debt ceiling a political football is nothing less than unConstitutional and thus breaking the law.  The Congress spent the money and the debt "shall not be questioned."  True, future spending is the political issue and legitimate arguments can be made but the debt ceiling is not. The Tea Party Republicans may proclaim to be strict adherents to the Constitution but clearly only adhere to those parts that fit their simplistic ideology and ignore those parts that don't. No surprise there but Obama should simply remind them of the Constitution and then by executive order, tell the Treasury to release the funds. The full faith and credit of the US is maintained, the Constitution followed and let the Tea Party take it to the Supreme Court if it wants.

I agree that the debt ceiling should not be a bargaining chip. It would be smart to return to the Gephardt rule, which automatically raised the debt ceiling to match budgets approved by the Congress.

The President would be wise to take this to the American people, letting everyone know that failure to raise the debt ceiling threatens the nation's credit rating and therefore paves the path to fiscal hardship.

A straight-forward and easily understood way to frame the issue is that those who fail to raise the debt ceiling *threaten America's credit rating*, to the detriment of all.

great comment. the last sentence is so dead on. I would wonder about the "used to be a great country." I'm not so sure. Built on genocide and slavery.
Workers abused throughout the industrial age. Segregation, north and south.

Progress in the 50s an 60s I think was largely made possible by fear of
communism. US was battling for control of 3rd world. Soviet and Chinese
used the injustices of the US to create disaffection in the newly emerging countries. Plus great fear of communist revolution here. With the fall of the Soviet Union and globalization, it was the perfect moment for the new robber barons to take the initiative. They didn't suddenly decide to change things. The circumstances were now on their side. Ironically rising rights of Blacks made white union workers more conservative. Any talk of justice or equality or fairness would in their minds mean more for Blacks. Reagan used this to great advantage.

This used to be a great country until our 'job creators' decided that our job force could be demoted to third world peon status. It used to be that the fortunes of the rich depended upon having a healthy middle class in this country. If President Obama actually stands up and confronts this cabal I will be happily surprised, but hope dwindles.

President Obama will *NEVER* do such a thing.

He is constitutionally (lower-case-C) unable to do such a thing because it's simply not in his nature to be confrontational. That's why he constantly blames "Congress" and not "the Republicans in Congress". That's why he constantly gives away half his negotiating room before even beginning negotiations. That's why real health care reform was never even brought to the table, just this sham of insurance reform that we're now struggling with.

If President Obama wasn't such a milquetoast wimp, he would have never let Congressman Joe Walsh get away with calling him a liar on national TV, but he did, didn't he? Our President just stood there and took it. And the Republicans understood what had just been signaled even if most of the folks watching at home (and most of the Democratic leadership) didn't understand this, not one bit.

Perhaps he can also explain how Democrats intend to pay for an entitlement state we couldn't afford BEFORE the Affordable Care Act passed, let alone since. I've been waiting on that explanation since 2007. Perhaps we'll get it in 2013. Or don't you worry about such things?

During the upcoming State of the Union address, perhaps President Obama should educate the American people about this conflict.

Perhaps he should state clearly, in words that most would understand, just as Professor Kurgman has done in his superb column, that the Republican leaders intent, based on their earlier declarations, is to dismantle the New Deal,especially social security.

Perhaps in his own eloquent way he could explain that the Republicans lowered taxes, waged costly wars and instead of paying as we go, we borrowed trillions of dollars to finance these ill-advised wars.

Maybe he can explain how declarations by some Republican leaders openly explained that this scheme was designed to deplete funding for social security.

A few days ago, President Obama quoted Abraham Lincoln as saying that a president can do anything if he has public opinion behind him. It is doubtful that American public opinion would support a sinister scheme to dismantle social security.

This is clearly a battle for public opinion. He who wins that battle will win this crucial struggle.

It's hard to find reliable news sources, not pushing a political agenda, outside of their editorial pages. So long as you check in with Dean Baker's beat-the-press blog at CEPR, to get good at reading the NYTimes, it is well worth paying for, despite my anger at what I see as its financial industry tilt. NYTimes is still the best one-stop.

You want people who can write in plain English, have deep historical understanding, technical analytic skill & truly understand the sectors on which they report. Obviously, Dean Baker (read the nytimes article he wrote today), Mark Thoma, and Paul Krugman exemplify this. Nouriel Roubini's has a paywall. You'll find many others through links from them.

The liberals, or those concerned with the public good, include Brad DeLong and Krugman's blogs and op-eds, Ezra Klein and Greg Sargent's blogs at WAPO, and Mike Konczal's - worth reading by all persuasions.

I can't overemphasize Nate Silver's point: you need to know your strategic goals (and I'd add, their consequences).

There are good bloggers who, though liberal, help you understand issues & define your goals. The economist Duncan Black, digby's blog, Jonathan Chait, news mags like The New Republic & Washington Monthy & their blogs. Lots of intelligent but lyrical opinions from Charles P,. Pierce; digby's blog; tech left like Naked Capitalism. By skimming these you will find many other intelligent explainers. You'll learn, agree or not.

And, for a good time always call Wonkette ;)

I do not doubt Mr. Obama's commitment to reducing USA's income disparity anymore than I doubt the Republican's commitment to drowning all government in the tub in order to feed up public services to the private sector profit machine. But intelligent person also knows that the recent patchwork last-minute cliff deal was more the result of "fear of market reaction" than it was altruism.

It is more than a class war in America today, it is a war of ideology. I am sad when I see my homeland on its present path when it could easily become a vibrant driving economic force like Scandinavia. The key is an acceptance of government as a legitimate partner, a driver of that wild horse we call raw capitalism.

Until Americans unlearn their mistrust of government and accept its regulating role in society,they will always be stuck with the fact that in order to provide crumbs to the needy, banquets will first have to be served up for the wealthy.

Obama has at least twice (in 2011 and just recently, a month or so ago) said he does not believe the 14th amendment applies to the debt limit set by Congress and does not intend to use it. Let's hope he changes his mind if Congressional Republicans insist on a pound of flesh (ton of flesh?) for an increase in the debt limit, and does, indeed, invoke the 14th amendment or otherwise just goes on paying the federal government's bills & debts. Better a constitutional crisis than a financial crisis.

But if Obama is unwilling to invoke the 14th amendment or otherwise keep paying our bills & debts, then I'd prefer that we default rather than have Obama cave and agree to benefit and budget cuts that will hurt the economy and disproportionately hurt the poor and middle class. Because a financial crisis of the government not paying its debts--unlike a financial crisis of the banks and housing as we're still recovering from--will, I think, disproportionately hurt the wealthy class and other governments who hold so much of the debt. I realize no one knows what financial disasters will occur if the federal government defaults. The worst possibility I can imagine is that the U.S. dollar will cease to be the world's main market currency. That will take away a big advantage we've had for many decades. But it's worth risking that rather than hurting our recovery while unemployment is still so high or making our enormous inequality of wealth, income, and economic mobility even worse.

Now I buy them myself!

That's the great thing about data, it exists whether you believe it or not.

I honestly can't think of anyone I've known for 10+ years who has genuinely not changed in that time. And my friends/family are mild examples -- just think of the people who find religion/exercise/love/etc. and made radical, life-altering changes that last for decades.

It sounds like you made choices early on that worked for you, but not everyone does that. That doesn't mean they can't change.

Although this post appears to be asserting the opposite, it actually seems to be quite  consistent with the results these researchers are reporting: people do not expect to change in the future despite the fact that their pasts provide evidence of considerable change (in this example, the person is convinced that he or she won't ever change with regard to fitness, eating, and meditation, despite the evidence that she undertook what must have been a rather radical change in that regard 15 years ago).  One wonders what his or her position on this was, say, 17 years ago.  Was she imaging great changes in 2 years?  Or was she as convinced then that her habits were so settled that she would never be able to acquire and maintain a mediation practice for 15 years? What is interesting about this data is not that we are able to recall the past much better than we are able to predict the future.  As others have pointed out, that is not news.  What seems interesting, at least to me, is the idea that we apparently persist in this mistaken belief (from here on out I am likely to remain about the same) as we grow older, despite the increasing pool of evidence counter to this we leave trailing in our wake.

I don't believe any of this data, people who are fickle are that way for the rest of their lives. I've believed in fitness, no meat eating, and meditation for more than 15 years. It's no fad, these aren't  Ninja Turtles, I won't change because I'm reminded of their truths every waking moment I'm alive.

I listen to much the same music I as did when I was 7: not only Beethoven, Brahms, Verdi, Wagner, but also Strauss, Bartok, Stravinsky. I don't think there is anything unusual about a 63 year old listening to difficult classical music, but one of the great pleasures of 63 is buying a CD version of a disc I had at, let's say, age 11. My reading now is made up of those books I had no time to read when I was younger, although I did read Austin, Thackeray, Dickens, Mann, Dostoevsky, etc. IAny new authors who have entered my personal canon have done so on invitation from the authors already there. I am about to read the Tony Judt book _ _Postwar_. I suppose it is an upgrade from the Will Durant, Barbara Tuchman, Bruce Catton I read the year I turned 13 I still dress 98% of the time in the jeans and t-shirts, even if they are cut differently nowadays. My political views haven't changed at all.

You see, the teenager I was keeps a sharp eye on the adult I am. He is my ethical center and gives me hell if he thinks I am about to betray him. I turned out to be the adult he wanted me to be. I am never embarrassed by my younger selves. Much to the contrary.

This is an optimistic article. We, as individuals, learn, change and evolve through our life experiences. We should celebrate the fact that we change in unpredictable ways, depending upon the uncontrollable and chaotic trajectories of our lives.

It's not at all a mystery why we cannot imagine our future selves with the clarity we have for our prior versions. The past  and present are known, but the future is yet to be. So it is no surprise that we have little insight into what is not yet known. What wisdom provides, however, is the acknowledgement that change and chagrin are  inevitable.
